title: Manchester United must copy Liverpool blueprint, says Robbie Savage
text:
Robbie Savage has not enjoyed watching his former team Manchester United slip further and further behind Liverpool (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United will have a front-row seat to the performance of the team they should be trying to emulate when they take on Liverpool at Old Trafford tomorrow, according to Robbie Savage.

Jurgen Klopp’s side will travel to Manchester looking to keep up their 100 per cent record in the Premier League and arrive as even money favourites to do so.

The Reds have not won a league title in nearly three decades but are eight points clear at the top and are already a mammoth 15 points ahead of their bitter rivals United.

And Savage believes his former club must look at what Klopp has achieved since he took over at Anfield and learn from their example.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘United have spent £900m on new players since [Sir Alex Ferguson] stepped down – and they have gone backwards,’ Savage wrote in his column for the Daily Mirror.

‘Where, in Ferguson’s era, there used to be a nucleus of senior players calling the shots and leading by example for youngsters to follow, now there is too much dead wood cluttering up the squad.

‘And where young players used to give United pace and energy, they are now having to carry the team – Marcus Rashford, in particular, is showing signs of the burden turning to fatigue.

‘One problem is that the kids United are turning to – Scott McTominay has been a shining light among them – are not coming into the first team with a winning mentality.

‘Many of the youngsters coming through at Chelsea have won the FA Youth Cup several times, for instance, and their winning habit is making an immediate impact in the Premier League.

‘But United’s kids have not been serial winners at youth level. They are having to learn the art of winning on the shop floor, and that’s a huge ask.’

Is Marcus Rashford getting fatigued by the burden of responsibility? (Picture: Getty)

Liverpool meanwhile have built a team that has reached two consecutive Champions League finals, beating Spurs in the second one, and has its best chance in years to win a first Premier League title.

Winning that trophy would only serve to highlight the gulf between the two sides who Savage believes are now almost in different.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Savage added: ‘Klopp has spent £395million on new players since he became Liverpool manager in October 2015 – with a net spend of just under £70m.

‘In that time, he has delivered the European Cup to Anfield, reached four other major finals, and is currently sitting pretty on an eight-point lead at the top of the Premier League.

‘Contrast Klopp’s ascent with United’s wretched decline since Sir Alex Ferguson retired in 2013. Over the last six seasons, United have finished an average of 21.5 points behind the champions.

‘And although it pains me to say so, they are now an irrelevance in the title race.’
